Literature Review: The evolution of health technology design has increasingly emphasized the importance of human- and equity-centered approaches to bridge translational gaps and enhance health equity. Traditional technocentric views often overlook the broader socio-cultural and economic contexts in which technologies are deployed, leading to innovations that fail to meet the needs of diverse populations. This literature review explores the rationale for integrating stakeholder analysis and contextual investigation into health technology development and biomedical engineering education, reviews existing frameworks for human- and equity-centered design, and presents case studies that exemplify these approaches in medical device design. The shift towards human-centered design (HCD) in health technology emphasizes understanding the needs, behaviors, and environments of end-users and other stakeholders. HCD approaches advocate for iterative design processes that involve users from the early stages of development to ensure that the final product is usable, accessible, and meets the intended health outcomes. Equity-centered engineering further extends this by focusing on addressing disparities in health access and outcomes, particularly for marginalized and underserved populations. This approach requires a deep understanding of the social determinants of health and the systemic barriers that contribute to health inequities. Contextual investigation, a key component of HCD, involves immersive research methods to understand the environment and conditions in which a technology will be used. This includes ethnographic studies, interviews, and participatory design workshops that engage a wide range of stakeholders, including patients, healthcare providers, and community members. Such investigations can uncover unmet needs and potential barriers to adoption that might not be evident from a purely technical perspective. Stakeholder engagement is critical for the successful adoption of health technologies. Engaging stakeholders early and throughout the design process ensures that diverse perspectives are considered, leading to more inclusive and effective solutions. Frameworks such as the Stakeholder Engagement in Innovation and Development (SEID) model provide structured approaches for identifying and involving stakeholders in health technology projects. Case studies of medical device design that apply human- and equity-centered approaches demonstrate the potential of these methodologies to create impactful health technologies. For example, the development of low-cost, portable diagnostic devices for use in low-resource settings has benefited from extensive stakeholder engagement and contextual investigation, resulting in devices that are not only technically effective but also culturally appropriate and accessible to underserved populations. In conclusion, the integration of human- and equity-centered approaches into health technology design is essential for creating innovations that are truly responsive to the needs of diverse populations. By thinking beyond the device and engaging with the broader context and stakeholders, biomedical engineers can contribute to reducing health disparities and improving health equity.
